Aston Martin Lagonda Global Holdings PLC (AML:LSE): Last: 1,118, down 256.8 (-18.68%), High: 1,350, Low: 1,097, Volume: 385.88k
Tony Scott Outrageous costs associated with Aston Martin listing, someone was clearly behind on their bonus targets
Waterloo @dec69, a bit AC/DC then
Dec69 - Skeptic Indeed
11:19 am
BE11:19am

That's a record low, in case you're wondering. But it's off the back of a 12% rally Monday to Wednesday, largely in expectation of a sales beat.

Dec69 - Skeptic Is anyone not short Aston?
red @VV75not sure, car sales really dropping off cliff everywhere. stocks stopped going parabolic so bit less cash for rich to spend.
BE11:20am

Who can summarise? Caz maybe?

BE11:20am

Aston Martin (AML) reported FY18 revenues of €1.1bn in-line with our estimate of €1.05bn. Adj. Ebitda margin came in at 22.6% vs. guidance of ~23% and 6% ahead of our expectations. Adj. Ebit margin came in at 13.4% for 2018 vs. initial guidance of ~13%. For 2019, AML expects adj. Ebitda margin of ~24% and an adj. operating profit (EBIT) margin of ~13%. There is a one-off £20m benefit from the sale of intellectual property in 1H18, which will not repeat in 2019. This means to meet flat Ebitda margins y/y the company would need a 2% improvement in underlying earnings in 2019 (IFRS16 adds 1% to Ebitda margin). We think this mainly comes from the full year of the Vantage/DBS, removal of ramp-up costs and higher option contribution.

Dec69 - Skeptic Does the summary include $#!t with some glimmer of hope?
11:20 am
BE11:21am

The Rapide E, the first electric Aston, is coming this year BTW.

BE11:21am

That'll be exciting.

BE11:21am

Wholesales of 7.1-7.3k including specials and heritage models. Adjusted Ebitda margin of ~24% (vs. 22.6% in 2018) – it is expected to be lower year-on-year in the first half of 2019 principally due to the non-repeat of the £20m of other income relating to the sale of certain intellectual property in the first half of 2018. Adjusted operating profit (EBIT) margin: ~13%. No dividends have been paid or proposed as AML continues to invest in future growth and focus on the delivery of the Plan.

Tom Dalgleish Ferrari did similarly after listing
Dec69 - Skeptic Sounds like a Fiat or Renault (Pronounced Renfault), 'The Rapide E' brought to you by Aston.
Flaneur Should have just called it RapidE, no?
Punter Any grey please on TEF, down 16% thismorning on trading and strategy update?
11:21 am
BE11:22am

Cash generated from operating activities was adversely impacted by a significant increase in working capital, including receivables of ~£90m associated with supply chain delays during Q4 and the consequential shifting of wholesale deliveries to the end of the period. This is expected to substantially unwind during the course of H1 2019. Capex came in lower than guidance at ~£310m but this was mainly a timing impact. Guidance for 2019 is £320-340m (on tangible + intangible).

The problem with Aston, of course, is that it's priced as Louis Vuitton while being Burberry at best.

Dec69 - Skeptic means not missed*
BE11:24am

Ferrari appears to be the closest listed European peer group for investors,
given its business proximity, and the other peers being either private or part of a large group. AML shares trade at 31.4x earnings, 3x EV/Sales, and 23x EV/EBIT on our unchanged 2019E (17.4x, 2.25x and 14.2x respectively on 2020E), close to those of Ferrari (29x, 5.9x and 23.5x on 2019E), and at a large discount on 2020E (Ferrari on 27.2x, 5.6x and 20.8x respectively). Our current DCF uses a 9% WACC and 2.5% permanent growth rate, pointing to GBp1,469 fair value.

Ghazali Good morning all

Cracklenpop You may have discussed this yesterday but since when did it become the norm for companies like Metro Bank and M&S to announce capital raises without providing any detail on pricing?

SoS I hope the rapide E has the range to get to James Bond's old home up in Scotland
11:25 am
BE11:25am

2019 key expectations. The DBX, the company’s first SUV, remains on track for launch in mid 2020. The St Athan facility is materially complete and first production trials are due to start in Q2 2019. The Valkyrie, the group’s road legal hypercar and a key model in the specials line-up, remains on track for first deliveries in the current year. 2019 will also see full production run rate at Gaydon following the successful launch of the Vantage and premium DBS Superleggera in H2 2018. Given the current political situation the company has put a Brexit team in place with a budget of £30m primarily for advanced working capital to mitigate any potential supply chain disruptions.
● Forecasts. We have reworked numbers primarily to reflect further operating costs for St Athan coming through rather than capitalized, reduced our over-ambitious volume targets and taking into account IFRS16 impact of -£4m to PBT. 2019 EBITDA £306m from £326m, EBIT £166m from £185m. PBT £110m from £147m.

red but i suppose at least the parts bin has grown in quality as it used to be ford parts bins that they raided.
Tom Dalgleish Not a bargain yet
FS Any comments on Spire Healthcare's results?
Soundbuy How cyclical is the luxury end of the car mkt?
BE11:28am

Looking for a tombstone on the Aston Martin IPO, because those people have done well. The folk they stuffed shares, not so much.

undefined

Telford Homes PLC (TEF:LSE): Last: 293.00, down 57 (-16.29%), High: 313.50, Low: 285.50, Volume: 922.09k

BE11:29am

Straight up profit warning, expect £40m for FY2019 rather than the £46m forecast.

Soundbuy @Tony - always thought that the luxury end....more export driven may be a tad more immune
Dec69 - Skeptic Telford Homes, near 50% weighted towards build to Rent, what could possible go wrong?
11:30 am
BE11:30am

Peel Hunt's shop here.

BE11:30am

Conditions in the London residential sales market remain
subdued and combined with some planning and construction
delays, which are largely out of the group’s control, leads us to
materially reduce near term profit forecasts. However, Build to
Rent is to be a larger part of the business than previously guided
which will significantly de-risk the development pipeline,
underpin output growth and reduce gearing. We have lowered
our target price to 350p which we believe should be supported
by and is broadly in line with March 2020F NAV per share.

red i would think asia/china growth more linked to their prospects
Tony Scott @Red, agree. I dont think it is insulated at all, as people lose their jobs and companies cut back, that xmas bonus becomes a lot more important throughout the times people are unemployed
BE11:31am

Trading update – Since Telford’s last update, sales rates have slowed and higher incentives and discounts are being used to secure individual unit sales. This is leading to pressure on margins and management expects these conditions to persist into the next financial year to March 2020. There have been a number of issues with planning, including delays to two build contracts which will shift c£5m of profit into FY20. Delays to the construction programme at City North in Finsbury Park (due to reliance on third parties and transport bodies) have also led to a significant profit shift of £15m moving from FY20 into FY21.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Build to Rent de-risking the pipeline – The announcement of a new forward funded Build to Rent (BTR) partnership is expected from the group imminently. After a review of the balance of the business, management expects to change at least three sites from individual sale to BTR with around 50% of the pipeline made up of BTR and subsidised affordable housing. This proportion is expected to grow further with a sharper focus on de-risking the growth profile. BTR is a key part of increasing housing output in London, and Telford, with its
partnership, will be at the forefront of the delivery.

squarepeg Any comment around on DGOC figures?
BE11:31am

Lower gearing and net asset support – The forecast reductions (detailed
below) are primarily driven by the planning and construction delays and the shift to typically lower margin BTR. However, BTR also removes a significant amount of market risk and requires no debt and limited equity for development. We now expect gearing to be lower than 50% in FY19 (previous estimate c62%) with a move to c30% over the next 2-3years. All of Telford’s sites are expected to contribute to profit growth over the next few years, providing support for our forecast NAV of 342p for the year to March 2020.

BE11:31am

Forecasts and valuation – For the year to March 2019 we reduce PBT from
£46m to £40m. The reductions in FY20 are significant moving from £48m to £24m, and from £50m to £30m for FY21. Management is targeting PBT growth back to the revised FY19 levels by FY22. The dividend paid in FY18 of 17p is also expected to be maintained for the forecast period, reflecting the confidence in the medium term growth prospects and the strengthening balance sheet. On revised forecasts the shares trade on a FY20 P/NAV of 1.0x with a dividend yield of 5%.

Tony Scott @Soundbuy, depends on how secure you think the global economy is at the moment. Recessionary pressures in Germany and France and Chinese central bank rumblings may slow down exports in the short term

11:36 am
BE11:36am

And that's an earnings miss post a profit warning, so no surprise to see them down.

BE11:36am

Panmure can summarise:

BE11:37am

The 2018 results were well behind our forecast with an Operating Result of £517m (-22%) which compared to our forecast of £579m and consensus at £561m. The performance was driven by an underwriting result of £250m (-37%) which in turn reflected a COR in Canada of 97.6% (2017:93.9%), Scandinavia at 86.8% (2017: 82.9%) but a very disappointing UK and International at 101.4% (2017: 100.5%). The pre-tax profit at £480m (+7%) compared to our £546m forecast and consensus at £523m.
The full year dividend was 21.0p/share (+7%) bang in line with consensus at 21.0p/share reflecting a final dividend of 13.7p/share (+5%). The Net Tangible Asset Value (essentially the NAV ex goodwill) was 279p per share (2017: 270p, H1 2018: 285p) which compared to our, and consensus, 286p forecast.
The Group Combined Operating Ratio (COR) was disappointing at 96.2% (2017: 94.0%, H1 2018: 94.7%) reflecting the volatility and poor results in the London market that was flagged in September. The COR compared to consensus at 95.2% and our 94.6% forecast.
The underlying return on tangible equity (ROTE) was 12.6% (2017: 15.5%), a miss on consensus at 13.9% and well behind our 14.4% forecast. It fell outside the bottom end of RSA’s target range of 13% to 17%. The Solvency II coverage ratio at

11:37 am
BE11:37am

.... 170% (net of the final divi) was good and compared to its target range of 130% to 160%.

Dec69 - Skeptic What's the implications for Howden's Joinery now its growth has peaked and margins under pressure?
BE11:38am

In our view the recent issues in the UK highlight the uncertainty in the risk
business. The UK market remains a competitive place and RSA rather bizarrely for an insurance company says that the results demonstrate too much exposure to market volatility. There have been management changes (Head of UK has gone) but we remain surprised that control seems to have slipped to the extent that it appears to have.

BE11:38am

 Investment view – We main our HOLD recommendation with unchanged target price of 578p but anticipate that the shares will be under pressure short term given the disappointing results. We value the stock on 11.8x 2019E PE with a 4.5% dividend yield
in FY19E. The shares are currently trading on 10.7x 2019E PE multiple and 1.9x 2018 TNAV per share. We view RSA as being close to fully valued and such multiples as full given the relatively challenging market conditions in which RSA is trading, particularly in the UK.

rw42 I remember seeing adverts for a BTR site in wembley on the tube before - it was amazingly difficult to find out what the costs to rent a unit would be unless you signed up to get a tour!
11:39 am
BE11:39am

And Goldman.

BE11:39am

The update points to disappointing underwriting trends, with all key geographies delivering weaker current year loss ratios than we had expected for 2018. Supportive market conditions in Canada and strong pricing power in Scandinavia should allow the group to address the issue in these markets, leaving the UK as the main challenge for the group. The stock underperformed the index by 7% in the last 3 months, so the weakness may partly have been anticipated by the market. Further, we consider the outcome of the triennial pension review to be reasonably benign.

BE11:44am

..... none of which should be a huge surprise. Here's JPM.

BE11:44am

Howdens reported underlying PBT of £242.3m for FY18 (adding back a £3.8m GMP Equalisation charge), which was in line with JPMe £242.7m. It looks to us that Howdens did not finish FY18 strongly, although this appears to have improved in the first two months of 2019 (LFLs: 2.4%). UK same depot growth for the year was weaker than expected at 6.3% vs. JPMe 8.0%. Gross margin was down 160 bps to 61.7%, 30 bps below our estimate of 62.0%. Howdens refers to having given depots 'more flexibility on margin' and experienced higher costs, resulting in lower gross margins. EPS was 31.3p, 4% below JPMe 32.5p. DPS is 11.6p, 4% below JPMe 12.1p. Net cash is better than forecast at £231m (JPMe £202m). A new £50m buyback has been announced. We are Neutral, with a price target of 480p, Dec-19.

18 new kitchen ranges were introduced vs. 26 the year before, says JPMorgan.

BE11:45am

chopper bear petrofac?
BE11:45am

UK same depot growth was 2.4% (3.5% adjusted for one fewer trading days) in the first two periods of the new year to 23rd February. The company expects further operating costs of c£15m to close some European operations as well as new depots and inflationary pressures. Howdens appear guarded on their outlook and direction going forward, remaining “cautious” given economic uncertainties.

11:45 am
BE11:46am

BE11:46am

Which is what Stifel does.

BE11:46am

Headline numbers broadly in-line with our expectations, with adj. PBT of £242.3m excluding the GMP equalisation charge (vs Stifel £243.4). Whilst sales growth has been solid, margin pressure continues - excluding one-offs operating margins were down c.120bps YoY. In Europe, the group plans to add depots in France but exit the Netherlands and Germany. Sales growth in the first two periods of FY19 has been solid, with sales growth of 4%.

Punter @BE ta for helpful grey on TEF, Soundbuy assessment probably right
11:47 am
BE11:47am

Whilst we are admirers of Howden's entrepreneurial culture, comparatives for 1H19 are tough and the market backdrop subdued. Additionally, we expect ongoing supply chain and digital investments to provide further headwinds to margin progression over the medium-term.

Our target price of 400p for HWDN is based on a FY19E P/E of c.12x. The key risks primarily relate to UK macroeconomic conditions, better-than-anticipated execution and the pace of the UK depot roll-out differing significantly from our expectations.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Here's Citi nevertheless.

BE11:51am

Zalando’s 4Q results are marginally ahead of expectations and FY19
guidance is in line with consensus so we would not expect material changes to near term forecasts on the back of this statement. More importantly, Zalando has reiterated ambition to scale GMV to €20bn, targeting 2023/24 and implying CAGR of at least 21%. Zalando claims to have resolved issues on PP through 2018 and therefore this GMV target includes at least 40% of GMV through PP, with 75% of this to be done through ZFS long term. Long term it is targeting a 10-13% adj group EBIT margin, including 6-8% for wholesale and 20-25% for PP. To get to these targets Zalando is guiding to EBIT margins of 2-4% and FCF negative across FY19-21e (Citi 2021e adj EBIT margin 4.2%, FCF margin 1.1%) which is likely to be focus of investors worried that business focusses too much on growth and too little on profitability.

red poss law of diminishing returns for online rag trade
BE11:52am

Hm. FY capex of €285m and a cash outflow of €70m

11:52 am
BE11:53am

Websites sure are expensive, in a way we were always told they weren't.

BE11:53am

Caz again.

Tom Dalgleish @Red, as a student coder, I can say that the digitisation of everything is the same as any other arms race
red think websites are expesnive because it firms building and running them want it to be so
BE11:53am

In our view this is a better than expected set of results from Zalando and we expect the stock to open higher. Q4 sales growth of 24.6% is slightly ahead of company collated consensus for 23.8% (albeit supported by higher discounting activity with the gross margin -150bps yoy in the quarter, JPMe -30bps). Q4 EBIT of €117.8m (margin 7.1%) is a 12% beat (cons margin 6.4%), driven by a lower fulfillment cost ratio than we had anticipated (supported by both a lower order split and returns rate which we think will be welcomed by investors given the attention on average basket value). Furthermore, the FY 19 outlook is in line with consensus and better than feared by investors ahead of today: FY 19 revenue growth is still expected to be within the target corridor of 20-25% (albeit at the low end of the range, although this dynamic versus higher GMV growth has been consistently called out by Zalando, FY 19 cons revenue +21% yoy); and implied FY 19 EBIT margin guidance of 2.7% to 3.5% is better than feared (cons 3.1%, but we think investors’ expectations had moderated to levels below this ahead of these results). The mid-point of the FY 19 EBIT guidance at €200m is c.2% below cons for €205m (i.e. also better than feared).

Viking1 Red Exactly
11:58 am
BE11:58am

Here's Barclays.

BE11:58am

A cash positive balance sheet for Petrofac, a major milestone in our opinion, will likely be offset by insipid commentary around the bidding pipeline. The near-term is likely to see low activity and the company is only targeting a book:bill of 1x. Whether this is just timing or related to impacts of the on-going investigations awaits clarification. Given recent performance of the stock, the results should have a neutral impact.

· Petrofac reported 2H18 revenues of $3,044mn, missing our estimates by 7% and consensus by 5%.

· Divisionally, E&C revenues of $2,141mn were 13% lower than our forecast, EPS ($767mn) were2% higher and IES ($146mn) were 8% higher.

· EBITDA totaled $346mn, missing our estimates by 7% but in-line with consensus.

· Divisionally, E&C EBITDA of $197mn was 20% lower than our forecast, EPS ($65mn) was 6% higher while IES ($96mn) was 44% higher.

· 2H18 order intake was $1.7bn vs 3.3bn at 1H18 and 3.5bn at 2H17 while backlog stood at $9.6bn vs 9.7bn at 1H18.

· The company reported a net cash position of US$490mn, versus previously indicated net debt of US$250mn.

· FY dividend of US$0.38/share is flat y.o.y and in-line with our forecast.

Summary via Barclays (again).

BE12:06pm

FY18 adj. diluted EPS of 296.7p vs. Barclays at 291.4p (consensus 290.6) – 12% organic EPS growth. This is the same as PM bulls used to aspire to, despite the fact that PM removes transaction currency impact and BAT does not.

· 2019 EPS growth expected to be high single digit at constant currency.

· NGP revenues of 901mn vs. 900mn expected. £5bn NGP revenue target has been pushed from 2022 to 2023-24.

· FY18 Net debt/EBITDA is at 4x - higher than the 3.9x we expected.

· Finance director Ben Stevens is retiring, with Tadeu Marroco being appointed as the new CFO. This is another internal appointment.

· FY18 organic revenue growth of 3.5% vs. Barclays 3.4%. Volumes of -3.5%.

BE12:07pm

Context via Citi (again).

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

We believe this set of results will do little to resolve the debate
about BAT. Bulls can argue that its 2018 EPS and 2019 guidance shows nothing has really changed in its earnings algorithm, and that this means its current P/E is therefore far, far too low. Bears can argue that it isn’t proactively adapting itself to the New World of Tobacco. They would say that (1) it increased its investment in NGPs in 2018 only in response to the unexpected U.S. tax cut, (2) it’s a long way behind in both heated tobacco and vapour, and (3) all other competitors are rapidly upping their game. At this point we retain our Neutral rating. One critical factor in 2019 will be how its NGPs develop, and we think it is far too early to make a definitive call on these.

And that seems to be a precedent. Here's Citi (again! Sorry. Citi.)

12:11 pm
BE12:11pm

We now expect a complicated ruling, which is likely to be appealed to the
Supreme Court of Canada – The oral hearing for the Appeal was heard in Quebec in November 2016. The long delay suggests the judges hearing the case may have been divided, implying a complicated ruling. Whatever the outcome, we expect a further appeal to the Supreme Court in Ottawa. The SCC will probably take about 6 months to decide whether to hear the case. If it does, then we will have to wait several more years before we hear the final outcome.
 However we think it is likely that the Canadian subsidiaries will be put into Administration – ITCAN has a 48% share of the legal cigarette market in Canada, and BAT has said several times that it might well put ITCAN into Administration, which is the Canadian equivalent of Chapter 11, perhaps even if the Quebec ruling is positive. We think that ultimately all the Canadian cases need to be settled, and that the best way of starting negotiations is to put the legal industry into bankruptcy Administration, and threaten to close it down. However, we think this sort of negotiation would take many, many years.

BE12:16pm

Here's a wall of text from James Hamilton at Numis on Arrow Global.

12:16 pm
BE12:16pm

Arrow reported total income (net interest income plus fee income) growth of 13.4% to £313.0m against our forecast of £296.9m with external Asset Management income increasing to 25.4% of group income from 22.7% last year. Despite the mix shifting to the higher cost Asset Management business, the group Cost:Income ratio still managed to decline to 73.9% from the 74.2% reported last year and the operating profit increased 14.8% to £81.7m. The group's 120m ERC increased by £191.9m or 10.8% to £1,972m and despite this growth in the balance sheet Net debt:Adjusted EBITDA declined to 3.7x from 3.9x. With the growth in the balance sheet forecast to slow we expect the group's leverage to decline further even as its dividend payments increase. The amortisation charge as a share of collections increased to 34.5% from the 29.3% reported last year and we expect that this ratio will increase to 42.4% over our forecast period as the ERC growth slows. Arrow continues to outperform its collection targets and cumulatively it now expects to collect 104% of its original target up from its previous estimate of 103%. The IRR (after collection costs) from the 2018 portfolio purchases is expected to be 17% against the 15% forecast from the 2017 portfolios. Arrow is an exceptionally high return business with the 2018 group ROE increasing to 34.8% from the 32.9% reported in 2017. Arrow delivered underlying EPS growth of 13% to 36.7p which was exactly in line with our estimate and the dividend increased 12% to 12.7p which was a little ahead of our 12.5p forecast. Consequently, the market is valuing Arrow at a multiple of 4.9x historic earnings with a historic yield of 7.1% and we expect continued good earnings and dividend growth over our forecast period. Our profit forecasts remain unchanged but EPS declines very modestly to reflect a higher tax charge, associated with the increased share of profit being derived from outside the UK.

And here's a couple of pars from Cazenove on Inchcape

BE12:18pm

Inchcape’s FY18 results are in line with our expectations, with group PBT
falling 2.6% y/y in constant FX. The dividend has been held flat. No change to
capital allocation policy, and we continue to forecast a buyback in FY19e.
Looking forwards, our group PBT forecasts (pre impact of IFRS-16) are
downgraded c.3%, due to a higher transactional FX impact than previously
expected. We remain OW with a Dec-19 price target of 803p (823p).

12:18 pm
BE12:18pm

Forecasts and Recommendation. Our forecasts now include the impact of
IFRS 16 which increases net debt by c.£460m and EBITDA by £80m and
decreases PBT by c.2%. Reported leverage therefore increases by c.0.9x.
Our “underlying” PBT forecasts, before the impact of IFRS 16, are
downgraded by c.3%, reflecting the higher Australian transactional FX
impact now expected. In the context of volatile markets, we think this is a
very credible outlook, particularly given Inchcape’s c.11% FCF yield.
Remain OW, TP falls to 803p reflecting forecast changes.

BE12:19pm

Mondi EBITDA rose +19% to €1,764m (+2% vs €1,734m cons) with profit growth in Fibre Packaging & Uncoated Fine Paper (UFP) divisions more than offsetting the weaker Consumer Packaging division. Underlying EPS rose +27% to €1.89 [+4% vs €1.81 cons], in the middle of the 15 Feb-19 pre-announced EPS range [€1.86 to €1.92]. Mondi delivered record 23.6% ROCE and, with a strong BS (1.3x FY18 net debt/EBITDA), raised the FY18 DPS to €0.76 (+4% vs €0.73 cons).

Soundbuy Cheers.......
12:19 pm
BE12:19pm

While Mondi acknowledges the macro uncertainties, it remains confident in the structural growth of its packaging sectors. The 2019 pricing outlook is mixed with weaker containerboard/pulp prices but stronger kraft/industrial bag/UFP prices. Positively, Mondi now guides to €50m EBIT in 2019 from completed capex projects. However, negatively, Mondi is also guiding to €150m 2019 maintenance costs (-€40m headwind YoY) & a slightly higher c23% tax rate (vs 22% previously).

BE12:19pm

In 2019 we model EBITDA broadly flat to €1,765m (FY18: €1,764m). Overall we expect 2019 EBITDA benefits from M&A (Powerflute) worth c€30m; major capex project returns worth €60m (guidance of €50m at EBIT); industrial bag/sack kraft price increases (worth greater than €50m) & higher uncoated fine paper (UFP) prices to be broadly offset by higher 2019 maintenance costs (worth -€40m), lower benchmark containerboard prices (worth -€100m) & modest input cost inflation.

BE12:20pm

We lower FY19-21E EBITDA -2%, with the c2% FY18 EBITDA beat to Jeff/cons offset by lower containerboard price assumptions of -€60/t (vs -€40/t previously) and -€40m higher 2019 maintenance costs. With higher depreciation, finance costs & a higher c23% tax rate (vs 22% previously) we lower FY19-21E EPS -4%. Our PT increases to 2,050p (from 1,950p) driven by higher 5yr avg EV/EBITDA multiples (vs 10yr previously).
